issues.description: The problem statement (UML) declares lectureName as a String, but the solution introduces a new LectureName class and declares the lectureName attribute as type LectureName. This diverges from the specification students see in the exercise and from the expected simple String field, and will confuse students about the intended type for lectureName (and likely break any tests that expect a String).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution use a String for lectureName (matching the UML and problem statement): change the Lecture field and constructor parameter to String, or if the intent is to introduce a LectureName wrapper type, update the problem statement and template (UML, method signatures, and instructions) to document and expect the LectureName type consistently. Prefer changing the solution to String to match the exercise.

issues.description: The constructor in the solution accepts a LectureName as the first parameter, whereas the problem statement specifies a constructor that initializes lectureName as a String and follows the attribute order from the UML. This constructor parameter type mismatch prevents students from following the specified signature/order.
issues.suggested_fix: Adjust the solution constructor to accept a String for lectureName and keep the parameter order specified in the UML (lectureName: String, numberOfInscribedStudents: int, numberOfGuestStudents: int, numberOfLecturers: int, numberOfTutors: int). Alternatively, if LectureName is intended, update the problem statement and template to require LectureName consistently.

issues.description: The solution's getter and setter for lectureName have inconsistent types compared to the backing field: getLectureName() is declared to return String and setLectureName(String) accepts a String, but the field is of type LectureName. These mismatches cause compilation errors and make the solution inconsistent internally and with the problem specification which expects a String lectureName and corresponding getter/setter.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the getter and setter types consistent with the field. If the field is changed to String (recommended to match the problem), declare: private String lectureName; public String getLectureName() { ... } public void setLectureName(String lectureName) { ... }. If LectureName is intended, change the getter/setter signatures to use LectureName and update the problem statement/template accordingly.

issues.description: The problem statement and UML describe the lectureName attribute as a String (attribute 'lectureName' of type String). The solution introduces a new type/class LectureName and uses it as the type of the lectureName field (private LectureName lectureName) and a Lecture constructor parameter, while still declaring getLectureName()/setLectureName() with String signatures. This introduces a new identifier (LectureName) for the same conceptual entity (the lecture's name) that is not present in the problem or template and creates a type/signature mismatch in the solution. Students expecting lectureName to be a String (as stated in the exercise) will face cognitive mapping confusion: is lectureName a plain String or an instance of a custom LectureName class? The inconsistent getter/setter signatures in the solution further obscure the intended mapping.
issues.suggested_fix:
Align the representation of the lecture name across artifacts. Two viable fixes:
1) Keep the exercise as written (lectureName is a String): change solution Lecture.java to use a String lectureName field, update the constructor parameter to String, and remove the LectureName class. Ensure getLectureName()/setLectureName() return/take String.
OR
2) If a LectureName wrapper type is intended pedagogically, update the problem statement and template to mention/use LectureName (and adjust UML/type in documentation) and make the solution's getter/setter signatures consistently use LectureName. Either option removes the mixed identifiers and type/signature mismatch.
